bug.author: naurojr
bug.description: I've tried to install it in a MAC using PIP and PIP3 and I get the same error: Command "/usr/local/opt/python/bin/python3.7 -u -c "import setuptools, tokenize;file='/private/var/folders/0s/rkvsfhzn2930_3902mpks9lm0000gn/T/pip-install-3cscl6kq/watchdog/setup.py';f=getattr(tokenize, 'open', open)(file);code=f.read().replace('\r\n', '\n');f.close();exec(compile(code, file, 'exec'))" install --record /private/var/folders/0s/rkvsfhzn2930_3902mpks9lm0000gn/T/pip-record-qr49cvd0/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile" failed with error code 1 in /private/var/folders/0s/rkvsfhzn2930_3902mpks9lm0000gn/T/pip-install-3cscl6kq/watchdog/ I'm using: macOS Mojave 10.14.5

Same error when installing watchdog for me.
I could not install streamlit in Windows Comandprompt but I could install it in AnacondaPrompt so you should try it !!

I saw a comment from <denchmark-link:https://medium.com/@MarkConway/you-may-get-an-error-installing-watchdog-on-the-mac-with-the-pip-install-command-first-do-this-bb277dafe5f1>Mark Conway</denchmark-link> saying that you need to install watchdog first and then install streamlit <denchmark-code>conda install -c conda-forge watchdog
Then:
pip install streamlit </denchmark-code>
That works for me with Python 3.7 macOS Mojave 10.14.5 conda 4.7.10

<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
This issue came up for another user today in live testing. The user was using a several-year's old MacBook
conda: 4.5 pip: 19.3.1 which pip: /usr/local/anaconda3/bin/pip
<denchmark-h:h2>Imporant note: the user's gcc installation was broken</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>XYZ-MacBook-Pro:~ xzy$ gcc xcrun: error: invalid active developer path (/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools), missing xcrun at: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/xcrun XYZ-MacBook-Pro:~ xzy$ which gcc /usr/bin/gcc XYZ-MacBook-Pro:~ xzy$ gcc xcrun: error: invalid active developer path (/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools), missing xcrun at: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/xcrun </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Side note: trying to install xcode didn't help</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>XYZ-MacBook-Pro:~ xzy$ xcode-select --install xcode-select: note: install requested for command line developer tools XYZ-MacBook-Pro:~ xzy$ xcode-select --reset xcode-select: error: --reset must be run as root (e.g. `sudo xcode-select --reset`). I've been reading the bugs above and have a suggestion for how this could be fixed. <denchmark-h:h1>Desired Behavior</denchmark-h>
At install, automagically detect that watchdog won't be installable and use the python fallback. After a (presumably) successful installation and upon a first streamlit command run, suggest that the user install watchdog on thier own (ideally recommending conda since they're in a conda environment.) As decribed here, the correct command is:
<denchmark-code>conda install -c conda-forge watchdog </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>More Details</denchmark-h>
This desired behavior presumes we can detect environments where watchdog won't work. Two possibilities:
On the extreme of guaranteeing a successful installation, we could say that streamlit work for any conda environment. On the other extreme of trying to maximize the chance that watchdog is installed automatically, we could try to pre-figure out whether pip installing watchdog will fail. This would be easy in the case just above because gcc wasn't working, but I'm not sure that would cover every case users are seeing.
I think we should do (1) because:
This approach maximizes the probability that installation will succeed. It's not clear (to me) from the examples above how we could design such a test that the watchdog install will work. (I do not think a valid watchdog installation check would be to try installing watchog manually in setup.py since this would break dependency checking.)

Can someone try the following? Depending on your setup, a different combination of the commands below should work <denchmark-h:h3>This will bring up a prompt to install the necessary command line tools.</denchmark-h>
sudo xcode-select --install <denchmark-h:h3>Agree to the license afterwards</denchmark-h>
sudo xcodebuild -license <denchmark-h:h3>You may need to run reset</denchmark-h>
sudo xcode-select --reset <denchmark-h:h3>Agree to the license afterwards</denchmark-h>
sudo xcodebuild -license <denchmark-h:h3>If you'd only like the tools without xcode, download and install them from apple</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-link:https://developer.apple.com/download/more/>https://developer.apple.com/download/more/</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h3>Agree to the license afterwards</denchmark-h>
sudo xcodebuild -license <denchmark-h:h3>Try setting the path for the active developer directory to one of these locations. Try each one if no success.</denchmark-h>
sudo xcode-select --switch /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools sudo xcode-select --switch /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer sudo xcode-select --switch / Note, /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer maybe should be /Applications/Xcode.app <denchmark-h:h3>Agree to the license afterwards</denchmark-h>
sudo xcodebuild -license Note, not sure exactly when the license needs to be agreed to so I've included it after multiple steps. <denchmark-h:h3>After each set of commands, try the following to verify success</denchmark-h>
which xcrun gcc <denchmark-h:h3>And finally :D</denchmark-h>
pip install streamlit

I spent ~10 minutes looking into this to see if there's an easy patch for Watchdog, but I don't think there is. Recording some notes for posterity:
Xcode used to let you choose which macOS SDKs you wanted to install No longer! Now, in Catalina, it installs 10.15 and 10.14 SDKs If removing the 10.14 SDK fixes the issue for people we should figure out: -- Why is the 10.14 SDK being used? (Watchdog doesn't specify it, and the default SDK is 10.15) -- Is this a bug in the macOS SDK, or is Watchdog doing something bad? -- (Watchdog is not looking for a specific macOS SDK, so I don't think we can say “just don’t build against the Mojave SDK!”)

Per the forum just now, deleting the 10.14 SDK wasn't sufficient <denchmark-link:https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/unable-to-install-on-osx-10-15-5/3571/3?u=randyzwitch>https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/unable-to-install-on-osx-10-15-5/3571/3?u=randyzwitch</denchmark-link>

We're still looking into this, but nobody here has been able to repro it yet :/ However: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/sean-mcmann>@sean-mcmann</denchmark-link> , it looks like your issue is actually subtly different than the others, in that is actually while trying to compile the watchdog lib (rather than failing with a compile error). (I don't have a solution, just wanted to flag that there are potentially multiple issues being discussed.)

I was facing the same issue and the fix from <denchmark-link:https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/issues/628#issuecomment-581480649>here</denchmark-link> (as mentioned above) worked for me! <denchmark-code>rm -rf /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX10.14.sdk </denchmark-code>

if you have your own gcc install (find out by running which gcc) then pip uses it to compile watchdog which doesn't work even if you have Xcode tools installed. In that case, just temporarily move gcc somewhere and re run pip install streamlit
Hello <denchmark-link:https://github.com/zack-klein>@zack-klein</denchmark-link> ! Do we have to install the 10.14 SDK again or does Mojave runs fine even without it?
use pipenv for virtual environment instead..
I had the same problem! Try the following : pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel after that pip install streamlite
